title: Mutual Annihilation of Tiles

sections.text:
#### Abstract

Given $A \subset \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, the purpose of this article is to investigate when is the difference set $\Delta A$ disjoint with the zero set of the Fourier transform of $A$. In the study of tiles in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, the author observed an interesting phenomenon that if $(A, B)$ is a tiling pair with $|A|=|B|$, then sometimes $(A, B)$ is also a spectral pair and vice versa. Moreover, in such cases actually one of the components would have universality (i.e., it is the universal spectrum/tiling complement for its tiling complements/spectra). It turns out that the disjointness is the critical property here, and shall be analyzed using the symplectic Fourier transform. Under such configuration it is shown that the phenomenon persists either (1) if $A$ is an order $n$ subgroup, or (2) if $n$ is a prime number and $A$ complements an order $n$ subgroup, or (3) if $n=p^{2}$, and $A$ complements the non-cyclic order $n$ subgroup. A side result binding numbers of elements in different subgroups is also given.


Keywords: Fuglede conjecture; tiling sets; spectral sets; symplectic forms; exponential basis.

2020 MSC: 42A99; 05B45

*zwq@xzit.edu.cn

# 1 Motivation 

Let $\mathbb{Z}_{n}$ be the additive cyclic group with order $n$. A subset $A$ in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ is called a tiling set (or a tile) if there exists some $B \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ such that $\{A+b\}_{b \in B}$ forms a partition of $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n},(A, B)$ is then said to be a tiling pair in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ and we will write $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}=A \oplus B$. Alternatively $A$ is called a Euclidean spectral set if there exists some $S \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ such that $\left\{e^{2 \pi i\langle a, s\rangle / n}\right\}_{s \in S}$ forms an orthogonal basis on $L^{2}(A)$ with respect to the counting measure ${ }^{1} .(A, S)$ is then said to be a Euclidean spectral pair in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$. Here $\langle a, s\rangle$ is the usual Euclidean inner product. If $(A, B)$ is a tiling pair, then we will say that $A, B$ complement each other in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$. Alternatively if $(A, S)$ is a Euclidean spectral pair, then we will call $S$ a Euclidean spectrum of $A$.

A fundamental question of the sampling theory, known as the Fuglede conjecture [6], asks whether these two types of sets coincide. The conjecture has been disproved in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ for $d \geq 3[5,10,11,15,19]$, while for $d=1,2$ it remains open. Their coincidence in finite Abelian groups are equally important due to not only the wide application of discrete systems, but also its partial equivalence to the conjecture in $\mathbb{R}^{d}[1,8,13]$. On $p$-adic fields it is known to be true $[3,4]$.

So far there are quite a number of positive results in cyclic groups, in which the methods evolves. To keep the overall size of the paper short they are not to be fully listed here . For groups generated by two elements the number of results (all positive) are limited and methods therein are mostly combinatorial $[2,9,18,20]$.

In the study of tiles in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, the author observed an interesting phenomenon that if $(A, B)$ is a tiling pair with $|A|=|B|$, then sometimes $(A, B)$ is also a spectral pair. So why should we even consider taking $B$ as a spectrum of $A$ given that it already complements $A$ ? The initial motivation concerns the universal spectrum property. If $S$ is a spectrum for any tiling complements of $A$, then it is called a universal (Euclidean) spectrum for tiling complements of $A$. It is known that all tiling sets are spectral if and only if every tiling set admits a universal spectrum for its tiling complements $[5,11,14]$. Hence the starting point is to think reversely:

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ the notion of dual groups is avoided here to keep the notations simpler, also in the context of this paper it is more convenient not to distinguish them as we will be using tiling complement as spectrum directly.

In the tiling case, suppose that an order $n$ subgroup $H$ is complemented by $A$ in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}, B$ also complements $A$, and assuming the existence of a universal spectrum, then $B$ and $H$ should share this universal spectrum of $A$, a very natural choice of this spectrum would (though need not) be $A$ itself since it would be fairly trivial from Lemma 3 below that in this case $A$ and $H$ are actually spectra of each other ${ }^{2}$. A similar assertion can also be made for the spectral case.

The purpose of this article is then to investigate when is such an intuition true. Using symplectic Fourier transforms ${ }^{3}$ it is shown in Theorem 1 that the phenomenon persists either (1) if $A$ is an order $n$ subgroup, or (2) if $n$ is a prime number and $A$ complements an order $n$ subgroup, or (3) if $n=p^{2}$, and $A$ complements the non-cyclic order $n$ subgroup. Moreover, in all three cases one of the components actually has universality (i.e., is the universal spectrum/tiling complement for its tiling complements/spectra). The critical property (Lemma 6 below) is exactly the condition specified in [12] for universal spectra or universal tiling complements. A side result that may be useful in other contexts is the relation asserted in Lemma 4.

# 2 Preliminaries 

Given $x=\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right)$ and $y=\left(y_{1}, y_{2}\right)$, define the symplectic form between $x, y$ to be

$$
\langle x, y\rangle_{s}=x_{1} y_{2}-x_{2} y_{1}
$$

The symplectic form plays a vital role in time-frequency analysis since not only does it enter naturally in the definition of (one form of) pseudo-differential operators [7, Chapter 14.1] but also can it capture commutativity in finite Heisenberg groups (represented as discrete time-frequency shifts, see [21] and references therein).

For any subset $A$ of $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, denote the characteristic function on $A$ by $\mathbf{1}_{A}$ and

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ in the symplectic setting only, in Euclidean setting this is not always true, see Example 1 below.
    ${ }^{3}$ as will be explained in the next section it is important to use the symplectic transform here since otherwise the conclusion need not always hold.

then define its discrete Euclidean Fourier transform to be

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}(\xi)=\sum_{a \in A} e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{n} \cdot\langle a, \xi\rangle}
$$

and similarly define its discrete symplectic Fourier transform to be

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}(\xi)=\sum_{a \in A} e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{n} \cdot\langle a, \xi\rangle_{s}}
$$

Denote zero sets of these two transforms respectively by

$$
Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}\right)=\left\{\xi: \widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}(\xi)=0\right\}, \quad Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right)=\left\{\xi: \widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}(\xi)=0\right\}
$$

Further define the difference set of $A$ to be

$$
\Delta A=\left\{a-a^{\prime}: a, a^{\prime} \in A, a \neq a^{\prime}\right\}
$$

The difference set and the zero set are important since $(A, B)$ being a tiling pair in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ is equivalent to

$$
|A| \cdot|B|=\left|\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}\right| \quad \text { and } \quad \Delta A \cap \Delta B=\emptyset
$$

which is also the same as

$$
|A| \cdot|B|=\left|\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}\right| \quad \text { and } \quad\left(\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}\right) \backslash\{(0,0)\} \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}\right) \cup Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{B}\right)
$$

The latter inclusion is just an alternative way of stating that

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A} \cdot \widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{B}=\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}}
$$

which is also an immediate consequence of the convolution theorem that

$$
\mathbf{1}_{A} * \mathbf{1}_{B}=\mathbf{1}_{\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}}
$$

where $*$ is the convolution operator. Similarly $(A, S)$ being a Euclidean spectral pair is equivalent to $|A|=|S|$ and

$$
\Delta S \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}\right) \quad \text { or } \quad \Delta A \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{S}\right)
$$

We may analogously define a symplectic spectral set to be a subset $A \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ for which there exists some $S \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ such that $\left\{e^{2 \pi i\langle a, s\rangle_{s} / n}\right\}_{s \in S}$ forms an orthogonal basis on $L^{2}(A)$ with respect to the counting measure. $S$ is then called the symplectic spectrum of $A$ and $(A, S)$ is said to be a symplectic spectral pair. The universal (symplectic) spectrum is defined analogously.

It is also very easy to see that $(A, B)$ is a tiling pair in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ if and only if $|A| \cdot|B|=\left|\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}\right|$ and

$$
\left(\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}\right) \backslash\{(0,0)\} \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right) \cup Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{B}^{\text {sym }}\right)
$$

while $(A, S)$ is a symplectic spectral pair in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ if and only if $|A|=|S|$ and

$$
\Delta S \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right) \quad \text { or } \quad \Delta A \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{S}^{\text {sym }}\right)
$$

Actually $\left(s_{1}, s_{2}\right) \in Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}\right)$ implies $\left(-s_{2}, s_{1}\right) \in Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right)$, therefore the symplectic spectrum (resp. zero set) is just a 90 degree counterclockwise rotation of the Euclidean spectrum (resp. zero set). This simple rotation provides a new perspective which may reveal patterns that are not so obvious under the Euclidean setting.

Example 1. If $A=\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times\{0\}$, then $Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}\right)=\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n} \backslash(\{0\} \times \mathbb{Z})$ while $Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right)=$ $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n} \backslash A$, as describe by the figure below:
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Left: Euclidean zero sets;
![img-1.jpeg](img-1.jpeg)

Right: Symplectic zero sets

Proof of Lemma 1 to 3 below can be found in [21]: Lemma 1 is essentially [21, Lemma 2.3], Lemma 2 is [21, Lemma 2.2], Lemma 3 (i) is [21, Lemma 2.5], Lemma 3 (ii) is [21, Lemma 2.6]

If $h, h^{\prime} \in \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ satisfies $\left\langle h, h^{\prime}\right\rangle_{s}=1$, then they are called a pair of symplectic basis. In such case $h, h^{\prime}$ also generates $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$.

Lemma 1. If $H, H^{\prime}$ are two subgroups in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ with $|H|=\left|H^{\prime}\right|=n$ and $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}=$ $H \oplus H^{\prime}$, then for each generator $h$ of $H$, there is some $h^{\prime} \in H^{\prime}$ such that $h, h^{\prime}$ form a symplectic basis.

A symplectomorphism on $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ is a change of symplectic basis. In $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times$ $\mathbb{Z}_{n}$ symplectomorphism are precisely $2 \times 2$ matrices with unit determinants ${ }^{4}$. A symplectomorphism thus keeps the zero set invariant and changes neither spectrality nor the property of being a tile. One advantage of using symplectomorphisms is that whenever we are discussing complementing subgroups $H, H^{\prime}$ (or elements in them) as in Lemma 1, we can always without loss of generality assume that they are $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times\{0\}$ and $\{0\} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, which often facilitates computations and makes it easier to spot hidden patterns.

Now define the symplectic orthogonal set of a given $H \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ to be

$$
H^{\perp_{s}}=\left\{g \in \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}:\langle g, h\rangle_{s}=0, \forall h \in H\right\}
$$

If $H=H^{\perp_{s}}$, then $H$ is called a Lagrangian.
Lemma 2. Lagrangians in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ are precisely those order $n$ subgroups.
A quick way to justify Lemma 2 is to notice that if $H_{1}$ is the subgroup generated by $(a, 0)$, then $H_{1}^{\perp_{s}}$ is the subgroup generated by $(1,0)$ and $(0, n / a)$, similarly if $H_{2}$ is the subgroup generated by $(0, b)$, then $H_{2}^{\perp_{s}}$ is the subgroup generated by $(n / b, 0)$ and $(0,1)$, thus the symplectic orthogonal set of the non-cyclic subgroup $H_{1} \oplus H_{2}$ can be easily computed as

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(H_{1} \oplus H_{2}\right)^{\perp_{s}}=H_{1}^{\perp_{s}} \bigcap H_{2}^{\perp_{s}} \\
{ }^{4} \text { since }\left(\begin{array}{ll}
a & b \\
c & d
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
-1 & 0
\end{array}\right)\left(\begin{array}{ll}
a & c \\
b & d
\end{array}\right)=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
0 & 1 \\
-1 & 0
\end{array}\right) \text { implies that } a d-b c=1
\end{gathered}
$$

Lemma 3. Let $H$ be a subgroup of $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, then
(i)

$$
Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{H}^{s y m}\right)=\left(\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}\right) \backslash H^{\perp_{s}}
$$

(ii) $A \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ complements $H$ if and only if $|A| \cdot|H|=n^{2}$ and

$$
\Delta H^{\perp_{s}} \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)
$$

Lemma 3 (i) is actually the Poisson summation formula. Indeed, it merely states that if $H$ is a subgroup of $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, then

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{H}^{s y m}=|H| \cdot \mathbf{1}_{H^{\perp_{s}}}
$$

# 3 Main Results 

From now on we use $\langle x\rangle$ for the cyclic subgroup generated by $x$, and $\operatorname{ord}(x)$ for the order of $x$ in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$.

Lemma 4 (counting). Let $p$ be a prime number, $x \in \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$ with $\operatorname{ord}(x)=p^{m}$ $(m \in \mathbb{N})$ and $A \subseteq \mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$, if $x \in Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)$, then

$$
\left|A \cap\langle p x\rangle^{\perp_{s}}\right|=\left|A \cap\langle x\rangle^{\perp_{s}}\right| \cdot p
$$

Proof. Without loss of generality (by using a symplectomorphism) let us assume that $x=\left(0, n / p^{m}\right)$, then it is straightforward to verify that

$$
\langle x\rangle^{\perp_{s}}=\left\{0, p^{m}, 2 p^{m}, \ldots,\left(n / p^{m}-1\right) p^{m}\right\} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}
$$

and

$$
\langle p x\rangle^{\perp_{s}}=\left\{0, p^{m-1}, 2 p^{m-1}, \ldots,\left(n / p^{m-1}-1\right) p^{m-1}\right\} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}
$$

Setting $\omega=e^{2 \pi i / p^{m}}$ we get

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}(x)=\sum_{\left(a_{1}, a_{2}\right) \in A} e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{n} \cdot\left(a_{1}-\frac{n}{p^{m}}-a_{2} \cdot 0\right)}=\sum_{\left(a_{1}, a_{2}\right) \in A} e^{\frac{2 \pi i}{p^{m}} \cdot a_{1}}=\sum_{\left(a_{1}, a_{2}\right) \in A} \omega^{a_{1}}
$$

Thus $\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}(x)=0$ implies that

$$
\sum_{\left(a_{1}, a_{2}\right) \in A} \omega^{a_{1}}=\left(\sum_{j=0}^{p-1} \omega^{j \cdot p^{m-1}}\right) \cdot\left(\sum_{k=0}^{p^{m-1}-1} c_{k} \omega^{k}\right)
$$

with $c_{k} \in \mathbb{Z}$. Expand it further we obtain

$$
\left(\sum_{j=0}^{p-1} \omega^{j \cdot p^{m-1}}\right) \cdot\left(\sum_{k=0}^{p^{m-1}-1} c_{k} \omega^{k}\right)=c_{0}\left(1+\omega^{p^{m-1}}+\ldots+\omega^{(p-1) p^{m-1}}\right)+g(\omega)
$$

where

$$
g(\omega)=\left(\sum_{j=0}^{p-1} \omega^{j p^{m-1}}\right) \cdot\left(\sum_{k=1}^{p^{m-1}-1} c_{k} \omega_{k}\right)
$$

collects all terms of form $c_{j} \omega^{j}$ with $j$ being a number that is not divisible by $p^{m-1}$. Compare the part $c_{0}\left(1+\omega^{p^{m-1}}+\ldots+\omega^{(p-1) p^{m-1}}\right)$ in (3) with (2) we see that the terms $c_{0}, c_{0} \omega^{p^{m-1}}, \ldots, c_{0} \omega^{(p-1) p^{m-1}}$ ) must be obtained from elements in $A$ whose first coordinate is divisible by $p^{m-1}$, which are elements that also lie in $\langle p x\rangle^{\perp_{x}}$, i.e.,

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A \cap\langle x p\rangle^{\perp_{x}}}^{s y m}(x)=c_{0}\left(1+\omega^{p^{m-1}}+\ldots+\omega^{(p-1) p^{m-1}}\right)
$$

Counting the number of terms then shows that

$$
\left|A \cap\langle p x\rangle^{\perp_{x}}\right|=c_{0} p
$$

By the same reason it is also clear that

$$
c_{0}=\left|A \cap\langle x\rangle^{\perp_{s}}\right|
$$

Plug it back into (4) produces the desired result.
For each $k \in \mathbb{Z}_{p}$, if we denote

$$
V_{k}=\left\{j p^{m}+k p^{m-1}: j \in \mathbb{Z}_{d}\right\} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}
$$

then a careful inspection of (3) indicates that (4) can actually be expressed in the following more detailed way:

$$
\left|A \cap V_{0}\right|=\left|A \cap V_{1}\right|=\ldots=\left|A \cap V_{p-1}\right|
$$

Lemma 5. Let $p$ be a prime number, if $A \subset \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}}$ complements the non-cyclic Lagrangian in $\mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}}$, then

$$
A \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)=\emptyset
$$

Proof. Without loss of generality (by shifting, which does change $Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)$ ) we may assume that $0 \in A$. Suppose that the intersection is non-empty, and take $a \in$ $A \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{S}\right)$. In $\mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}}$ there is only one non-cyclic Lagrangian, which is the subgroup (denote it by $H$ ) that consists of all order $p$ elements. Therefore we must have $\operatorname{ord}(a)=p^{2}$ and $A$ consists of elements of form $(j, k)+h_{j, k}$ with $j, k$ both ranging from 0 to $p-1$, and $h_{j, k}$ being some element in $H$. Apparently $a \neq 0$ since $0 \notin Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{S}\right)$. Therefore $|A \cap\langle a\rangle| \geq 2$ since $A \cap\langle a\rangle$ contains at least 0 and $a$. Without loss of generality (by using a symplectomorphism) we may assume that $a=(1,0)$, then $\langle p a\rangle=\{(0,0),(p, 0),(2 p, 0), \ldots,((p-1) p, 0)\}$ and

$$
\langle p a\rangle^{\perp_{s}}=\mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times\{0, p, 2 p, \ldots,(p-1) p\}
$$

Thus

$$
A \cap\langle p a\rangle^{\perp_{s}} \subseteq\left\{(j, 0)+h_{j, 0}: j \in \mathbb{Z}_{p}\right\}
$$

i.e.,

$$
\left|A \cap\langle p a\rangle^{\perp_{s}}\right| \leq\left|\left\{(j, 0)+h_{j, 0}: i \in \mathbb{Z}_{p}\right\}\right|=p
$$

which is a contraction since Lemma 4 indicates that

$$
\left|A \cap\langle p a\rangle^{\perp_{s}}\right|=|A \cap\langle a\rangle| \cdot p \geq 2 p
$$

Lemma 6. Let $p$ be a prime number, if $A \subset \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}}$ complements the non-cyclic Lagrangian in $\mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}}$, then

$$
\Delta A \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)=\emptyset
$$

Proof. Assume the contrary that there exist distinct $a, a^{\prime} \in A$ such that $a-a^{\prime} \in$ $\Delta A \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)$.

Suppose that $H$ is the Lagrangian that $A$ complements, then $|A|=|H|$ and $\Delta A \cap \Delta H=\emptyset$. Consider now the set

$$
A^{\prime}=A-a^{\prime}
$$

which contains $a-a^{\prime}$, and thus

$$
a-a^{\prime} \in A^{\prime} \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)
$$

Clearly $\left|A^{\prime}\right|=|A|=|H|, \Delta A^{\prime}=\Delta A$ hold, hence $A^{\prime}$ also complements $H$. Consequently by Lemma 5 we shall have

$$
A^{\prime} \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A^{\prime}}^{s y m}\right)=\emptyset
$$

It is also easy to see that $Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A^{\prime}}^{s y m}\right)=Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)$, therefore

$$
A^{\prime} \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{s y m}\right)=\emptyset
$$

which contradicts (5).

The following example shows that the term "non-cyclic" in (ii) of both Lemma 5 and Lemma 6 can not be removed:

Example 2. Let $n=4, H=\{(0,0),(1,1),(2,2),(3,3)\}$, and

$$
A=\{0,1\} \times\{0,2\}=\{(0,0),(1,0),(0,2),(1,2)\}=\{(0,0),(1,0)\} \oplus\{(0,0),(0,2)\}
$$

It is straightforward to verify that $H$ is a cyclic Lagrangian, $A \oplus H=\mathbb{Z}_{4} \times \mathbb{Z}_{4}$, and

$$
Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right)=Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{\{(0,0),(1,0)\}}^{s y m}\right) \cup Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{\{(0,0),(0,2)\}}^{s y m}\right)=\left(\{1,3\} \times \mathbb{Z}_{4}\right) \cup\left(\mathbb{Z}_{4} \times\{2\}\right)
$$

$\Delta A$ is completely inside $Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right)$ rather than being disjoint with it.
Theorem 1. Let $p$ be a prime number and $n \in \mathbb{N}$, if one of the following three conditions holds:
(i) $A$ is a Lagrangian in $\mathbb{Z}_{n} \times \mathbb{Z}_{n}$,
(ii) $A \subset \mathbb{Z}_{p} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p}$ complements a Lagrangian in $\mathbb{Z}_{p} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p}$,
(iii) $A \subset \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}}$ complements the non-cyclic Lagrangian in $\mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}}$,
then $A$ is a symplectic spectrum for any of its tiling complements and a tiling complement for any of its symplectic spectrum.

Proof. Case (i) follows from Lemma 3. Case (ii) follows from case (i) since it is well known that any tiling pair in $\mathbb{Z}_{p} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p}$ must have one component being a Lagrangian $\left(\mathbb{Z}_{p} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p}\right.$ is a so called "good group", see the classification in [16, 17]). For case (iii) applying Lemma 6 we see that $\Delta A \cap Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right)=\emptyset$ holds. Therefore if $(A, B)$ is a tiling pair, then by (1) we must have

$$
\Delta A \subseteq Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{B}^{\text {sym }}\right)
$$

which implies that $A$ is a symplectic spectrum for $B$, while if $(A, S)$ is a sympectic spectral pair, then by Lemma 6 we have

$$
(\Delta S \cap \Delta A) \subseteq\left(Z\left(\widehat{\mathbf{1}}_{A}^{\text {sym }}\right) \cap \Delta A\right)=\emptyset
$$

which implies that $A$ is a tiling complement of $S$.
It is worth pointing out that in Theorem 1 (iii), $B$ or $S$ need not be the Lagrangian that $A$ complements (choices can be rich), otherwise the statement becomes trivial. The following example illustrates Theorem 1 (iii):

Example 3. Let $n=4$ and $A=\{(0,0),(3,0),(0,3),(3,3)\}$, clearly $A$ complements the non-cyclic Lagrangian $\{(0,0),(2,0),(0,2),(2,2)\}$. On the other hand, if $B=\{(0,0),(1,2),(2,0),(3,2)\}$, then $A$ complements $B$ as well, and as asserted in Theorem 1 (iii), $(A, B)$ is indeed also a spectral pair.

[7] K.Gröchenig: Foundations of time-frequency analysis. Springer, New York, 2013.
[8] A.Iosevich, M.Kolountzakis: Periodicity of the spectrum in dimension one. Analysis \& PDE, 6(4), 819-827, 2013.
[9] A.Iosevich, A.Mayeli, J.Pakianathan: The Fuglede conjecture holds in $\mathbb{Z}_{p} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p}$. Analysis \& PDE, 10(4), 757-764, 2017.
[10] M.Kolountzakis, M.Matolcsi: Complex Hadamard matrices and the spectral set conjecture. Collectanea Mathematica, 57, 281-291, 2006.
[11] M.Kolountzakis, M.Matolcsi: Tiles with no spectra. Forum Mathematicum, 18(3), 519-528, 2006.
[12] J.Lagarias, S.Szabó: Universal spectra and Tijdeman's conjecture on factorization of cyclic groups. Journal of Fourier Analysis and Applications, 7, 63-70, 2001.
[13] J.Lagarias, Y.Wang: Tiling the line with translates of one tile. Inventiones Mathematicae, 124, 341-365, 1996.
[14] J.Lagarias, Y.Wang: Spectral sets and factorizations of finite Abelian groups. Journal of Functional Analysis, 145, 73-98, 1997.
[15] M.Matolcsi: Fuglede's conjecture fails in dimension 4. Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society, 133(10), 3021-3026, 2005.
[16] A.Sands: On the factorisation of finite Abelian groups. Acta Mathematica Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricae, 8, 65-86, 1957.
[17] A.Sands: On the factorization of finite Abelian groups II. Acta Mathematica Academiae Scientiarum Hungaricase, 13, 153-159, 1962.

[18] R.Shi: Equi-distribution on planes and spectral set conjecture on $\mathbb{Z}_{p^{2}} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p}$. Journal of the London Mathematical Society, 102(2), 1030-1046, 2020.
[19] T.Tao: Fuglede's conjecture is false in 5 and higher dimensions. Mathematical Research Letters, 11(2-3), 251-258, 2004.
[20] T.Zhang: Fuglede's conjecture holds in $\mathbb{Z}_{p} \times \mathbb{Z}_{p^{n}}$. SIAM Journal on Discrete Mathematics, 37(2), 1180-1197, 2023.
[21] W.Zhou: A Fuglede type conjecture for discrete Gabor bases. Banach Journal of Mathematical Analysis, 18(51), 2024.

abstract:
Given $A\subset\mathbb Z_n^2$, the purpose of this article is to investigate
when is the difference set $\Delta A$ disjoint with the zero set of the Fourier
transform of $A$. In the study of tiles in $\mathbb Z_n^2$, the author observed
an interesting phenomenon that if $(A,B)$ is a tiling pair with $|A|=|B|$, then
sometimes $(A,B)$ is also a spectral pair and vice versa. Moreover, in such
cases actually one of the components would have universality (i.e., it is the
universal spectrum/tiling complement for its tiling complements/spectra). It
turns out that the disjointness is the critical property here, and shall be
analyzed using the symplectic Fourier transform. Under such configuration it is
shown that the phenomenon persists either (1) if $A$ is an order $n$ subgroup,
or (2) if $n$ is a prime number and $A$ complements an order $n$ subgroup, or
(3) if $n=p^2$, and $A$ complements the non-cyclic order $n$ subgroup. A side
result binding number of elements in different subgroups is also given.
